intro: Selinum livonicum, commonly known as the Livonia wormwood, is a perennial herb native to central and eastern Europe. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with slender stems and small, yellowish-green flowers that appear in umbels. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in wet meadows and along stream banks. Due to its rarity and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a protected species in several countries.
